<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/52  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 808, 91]]<|/det|>
A trolley with a magnet attached is placed on a thin steel sheet as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 98, 828, 291]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 303, 532, 321]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 333, 883, 352]]<|/det|>
The angle between the sheet and the bench is \(\theta\). The distance from point X to the trolley is \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 364, 918, 399]]<|/det|>
The trolley is released from rest and travels down the slope. The velocity \(v\) of the trolley at X is determined using a light gate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 411, 562, 430]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(v\) is related to \(\theta\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 435, 584, 465]]<|/det|>
\[m p\sin \theta -q B = \frac{m v^{2}}{2d}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 472, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
where \(m\) is the mass of the trolley and magnet, \(B\) is the magnetic flux density between the magnet and the steel sheet, and \(p\) and \(q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 520, 690, 538]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(v\) and \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 551, 625, 569]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 581, 698, 600]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(p\) and \(q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 612, 383, 630]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 643, 401, 661]]<|/det|>
· the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 667, 410, 685]]<|/det|>
· the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 691, 348, 708]]<|/det|>
· the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 714, 351, 732]]<|/det|>
· the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 737, 447, 755]]<|/det|>
· any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 848, 92]]<|/det|>
A student investigates a circuit containing a capacitor and a resistor as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 97, 710, 222]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 237, 532, 256]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 268, 920, 303]]<|/det|>
A dual-beam oscilloscope is connected across the capacitor of capacitance \(C\) and resistor of resistance \(R\). The oscilloscope displays two traces as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 312, 683, 572]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 588, 534, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 619, 703, 637]]<|/det|>
The student determines the phase difference \(\theta\) between the two traces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 650, 603, 668]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the experiment with different resistors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 681, 574, 699]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(\theta\) and \(R\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 707, 561, 734]]<|/det|>
\[\tan \theta = \frac{1}{2\pi fCR}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 742, 524, 761]]<|/det|>
where \(f\) is the frequency of the a.c. power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 772, 144, 791]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 771, 675, 794]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\tan \theta\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{R}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 804, 500, 822]]<|/det|>
Determine an expression for the gradient.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 913, 922, 932]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 490, 89]]<|/det|> Values of \(R\) and \(\theta\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 604, 120]]<|/det|> Each value of \(R\) has a percentage uncertainty of \(\pm 5\%\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 134, 541, 152]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[171, 160, 826, 448]]<|/det|>
\(R/\Omega\)\(\frac {1}{R}/10^{-3}\Omega ^{-1}\)\(\theta /\mathrm {}^{\circ }\)\(\tan \theta\)
1280.8
1677.5
2273.0
3365.2
3961.7
4359.3
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 457, 692, 490]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(\frac{1}{R}/10^{-3}\Omega^{-1}\) and \(\tan \theta\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 479, 518]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \(\frac{1}{R}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 496, 920, 514]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 526, 144, 544]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 524, 176, 544]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 522, 529, 549]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\tan \theta\) against \(\frac{1}{R}/10^{-3}\Omega^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 551, 395, 579]]<|/det|> Include error bars for \(\frac{1}{R}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 555, 920, 574]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 588, 176, 606]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 586, 920, 621]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 605, 920, 624]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 634, 178, 652]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 632, 920, 666]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 819, 920, 838]]<|/det|>
gradient = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
The student measured the frequency of the a.c. power supply twice. The student's values were \(101 \text{Hz}\) and \(97 \text{Hz}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 917, 121]]<|/det|>
Determine the average frequency \(f\) of the power supply. Include the absolute uncertainty in \(f\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 163, 920, 181]]<|/det|>
<form>f = .................................................... Hz [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 196, 144, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 196, 173, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 196, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (d), determine the value of C. Include an appropriate unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 412, 920, 430]]<|/det|>
<form>C = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 444, 181, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 444, 551, 462]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in C.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 584, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty in C = .................................................... % [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 615, 144, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 615, 751, 632]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated using the same power supply and capacitor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 630, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
Determine the resistance of \(R\) that would give a phase difference of \(40^{\circ}\) . Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 814, 920, 832]]<|/det|>
<form>R = .................................................... $\Omega$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 846, 920, 864]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 15]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 904, 920, 939]]<|/det|>
